To proof.

div.p: I have only time to give you a few lines & the accompanying receipt for the book you wanted which Mueller has shipped to you & Selwyn paid for as he said he had some cash of yours in hand. He wishes you very much to come over here to compare notes. The 5/- carriage is excessive on the value of the book, if Mueller gets a circulation of his books in Wellington out of the lists I have instructed him to send over he can then send boxes at trifling cost. I have told him to send lists to Mantell & yourself.
Mantell's Escalonia is doing well & I regret to say I have already got a little of Materas mixture at twice the Wellington cost.
I send you the title to my mare — not [new] I hope — with the shape of the sale notes that your may duly [convey].

Pray tell Mrs Stafford that I have sent a case of oranges from Sydney for her to Cap. Sharpe's care & beg her to accept them for little ones. I am writing so many notes & letters home & to New Z. that I cannot write Mrs S. Remember me kindly to Mr S & Miss Bentley.
Not further identified.
Tell Mantell I have seen Dr Mueller who is very ill. His is as thirsty for Ferntrees as ever & will liberally exchange. He is "too much obliged" to Mr Mantell & will be very glad to hear from him.
Trusting Coquette has given you no bother
